title: Beijing Suffers Major Loss from Its Hostage Diplomacy
description: China’s scheme to force Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou’s release by taking hostages backfired in ways big and small. China showed its teeth, but instead of cowering in fear, Canada and the United States held firm.

title: Facial Recognition Technology: Responsible Use Principles and the Legislative Landscape
description: The rapid development of facial recognition technology requires an exploration of how to use it responsibly, complemented in this report by an overview of the current U.S. legislative landscape.

title: Japan’s Ruling Party Elects a New Leader
description: Japan’s Liberal Democratic Party elected Fumio Kishida as its new leader and presumptive prime minister ahead of a general election later this fall. The CSIS Japan Chair outlines his policy platform, the political calendar, and the implications for U.S.-Japan relations.

title: What is the Significance of North Korea’s Rail-mobile Ballistic Missile Launcher?
description: While North Korea’s public demonstration of a rail-mobile missile launch platform earlier this month may have caught some by surprise, the country’s interest in developing such a capability reports back several decades.

title: Back to (Caring about) the Future
description: U.S. lawmakers and their staff will need to improve their use of foresight to ensure long-term national prosperity and security. In response, CSIS’s International Security Program and Congressional Affairs team partnered to create the Congressional Foresight Initiative.

title: U.S. Sanctions Squeeze Humanitarian Assistance in Afghanistan
description: As the humanitarian situation in Afghanistan deteriorates, the U.S. government should work with all stakeholders to establish a safe payment channel for humanitarian and organizations and financial institutions to move urgently needed funds into Afghanistan.

title: The Evening: Pfizer for Kids, DoD Warned on Afghanistan, Peace Train, and More
description: This edition of CSIS's nightly newsletter covers Pfizer for Kids, DoD Warned on Afghanistan, Peace Train, and More.

title: Intellectual Property versus Big Tech Platforms: The IP-Antitrust Paradox
description: If policymakers are concerned with stemming Big Tech firms’ growing influence, they should end the attack on intellectual property, as it is the most effective tool for stopping Big Tech’s increasing economic, social, and political concentration of power.

title: Overcoming the Tragedy of TPP
description: China’s application to join the CPTPP shines a spotlight on the United States’ own tragic error in walking away from TPP and not replacing it with something equally powerful. In mid-November, when he is center stage at APEC, President Biden has a chance to open a new act.

title: Previewing Japan’s Leadership Election and Implications for U.S.-Japan Relations
description: The Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) will host a telephone briefing on Tuesday, September 28, 2021, at 8:15 a.m. ET to preview the leadership election of Japan’s ruling Liberal Democratic Party scheduled for September 29.

title: All That Glitters Is Not Green
description: Carbon offsets can be a win-win situation: emitters invest in needed environmental projects, and environmental projects receive funding, leading greenhouse emissions to decline. However, carbon offsets are poorly regulated and can sometimes disincentivize decarbonization.

title: The Future of U.S. Leadership in Multilateral Development Institutions: A Playbook for the Next 10 Years
description: A new PPD report finds that U.S. global leadership in the multilateral system has waned over the past 30 years due to lack of government strategy, de-prioritization of multilateral system career paths, and a deficient approach to leadership and staffing within the system.
